en: This collection took place in a room on the ground floor of the west wing of the Château de Générac. This building dates back to the end of the 11th Century and its history is not at all banal. It was the vassalage of the Counts of Toulouse (a granddaughter of Raymond IV lived there) and remained a feudal residence until 1314. After the Treaty of Meaux, it passed to the Crown of France. A Commandery of Templars occupied it from 1248. Louis IX, it seems, had granted it to his knights as a reward for services rendered. Their persecutor, William of Nogaret, was in possession of this castle around 1300. It is said that he had it restored and fortified. When he died in 1314, the building passed to the Abbey of Franquevaux, then to that of Saint Gilles. In the 16th Century, the majority of the inhabitants of the village were in favour of the ideas of the Reformation. At the beginning of the XVIIth century, the Duke of Rohan, regional chief of the reformed, to protect his own people, set up a garrison in the castle. The west wing was probably built at that time to house the soldiers. The Hall, currently occupied by the Museum, was then used for religious practice. The name "Temple Hall" has remained. The project of its creation was born in 1989 and completed in 1995. It was inaugurated on 30 April 1995, the day of the Fête de la Souche, a ritual event in the commune of Générac, and will therefore celebrate its 20th anniversary. For centuries the commune has been an important centre of cooperage. For centuries the town has been an important centre of cooperage. While its neighbour, the town of Saint Gilles, specialised in making large oak tuns, Générac produced barrels with a capacity of 3 litres, the Barral, with a capacity of more than 500 litres, the Demi-muid, using the chestnut tree from Isère as raw material. The very flourishing activity goes hand in hand with an important wine production. It prospered until 1954, but suddenly fell victim to the entry into the era of plastic and systematic bottling. In addition, the wines of the Costières, whose ageing is limited, justify less than others a guard in barrels. At the time when it was discontinued, 120 to 150 families lived from this activity, and there were about ten companies with up to 20 workers. Each large farmhouse has a cooper at home, and making a barrel was a combination of only two ingredients, wood and iron, but to adjust the whole thing, what a skill it took! The cooper is in his own way a true goldsmith. He works with an exceptional precision, which leads to an assembly of elements that is absolutely watertight and by the play of geometry that comes especially at a glance. The wide variety of tools used is evidence of an elaborate technique. The Museum of Cooperage, at the Château de Générac, has an almost complete collection. So much so that one of our fellow-citizens, a former cooper, after observing it, said: "You have everything you need to make a barrel"! Guided and commented tour by appointment only.
